conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph for both cars to determine the collision time based on their braking process.
Car A starts at 25 m/s, and Car B starts at 15 m/s from the graph.
Both cars are decelerating at a rate of 2.5 m/s² as shown in the graph.
Calculate the distance each car travels before colliding using the formula: Distance = Initial velocity × Time - 1/2 × Deceleration × Time².
Since the cars start braking simultaneously, the time to collide is the same for both cars.
Set the distances equal using the formula: 25 × t - 1/2 × 2.5 × t² = 15 × t - 1/2 × 2.5 × t².
Simplify and solve the equation: 25t - 1.25t² = 15t - 1.25t², resulting in t = √10.
Convert the time to seconds before the collision: 20 + √10 ≈ 23.16.
Determine whether the time is before or after 20 seconds; since √10 ≈ 3.16, the time is after 20 seconds.
Conclude that the two cars collide after 23.16 seconds of braking.
The final answer is that the collision occurs after 20 seconds.
